title: 110_hr3146
content: The Act titled "Combating Terrorism Financing Act of 2007" addresses interstate transportation of criminal proceeds and "reverse" money laundering. The Act "Combating Terrorism Financing Act of 2007" amends Section 1957(a) of title 18, United States Code, regarding monetary transactions involving property derived from unlawful activity exceeding $10,000. Transporting more than $10,000 in currency in interstate commerce is also addressed. The Act "Combating Terrorism Financing Act of 2007" amends Section 1957(a) of title 18, United States Code, regarding monetary transactions involving property derived from unlawful activity exceeding $10,000. It addresses transporting currency in interstate commerce with the knowledge that it is derived from or intended for unlawful activity. Amendments to Section 1957(b) and (c) are made to specify penalties and incarceration periods for offenses related to promoting unlawful activities. The Act "Combating Terrorism Financing Act of 2007" amends Section 1957 of title 18, United States Code by clarifying the definition of "conducts" and expanding the heading to include support of criminal activity. The "Combating Terrorism Financing Act of 2007" amends Section 1957 of title 18, United States Code to include conducting monetary transactions in property derived from unlawful activity or in support of criminal activity. It also allows for freezing bank accounts of persons arrested for offenses involving the movement of money across international borders. Section 981(b) of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow the Attorney General to apply for an ex parte order to restrain accounts of individuals arrested or charged for offenses involving funds moving into or out of the United States. The order can last for up to 30 days, with the possibility of extension for good cause shown. The court can consider evidence that may be inadmissible under the Federal Rules of Evidence. The application for a restraining order must identify the offense, location, and accounts to be restrained to prevent the removal of funds by the person arrested or charged or others associated with them. "A restraining order may be issued if a person is arrested or charged with an offense that allows for forfeiture. The term 'account' includes safe deposit boxes and accounts at financial institutions. Restraint under this order aims to prevent the removal of funds by the person arrested or charged." "A restraining order issued under this paragraph allows for restraint of the subject account to prevent fund removal. It is not considered a seizure under subsection 983(a) and can be executed in any district or transmitted to a foreign state for service." The amendment to Section 5316 of title 31, United States Code, states that a monetary instrument with the amount left blank will be considered to have a value exceeding $10,000 if drawn on an account with more than $10,000. Additionally, Section 1956(a)(1) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include monetary transactions in the prohibition of money laundering through informal value transfer systems. SEC. 6. SECTION 1957 VIOLATIONS INVOLVING COMMINGLED FUNDS AND STRUCTURED TRANSACTIONS. This section of the United States Code is amended to allow the Government to meet the $10,000 requirement by showing transactions involving more than $10,000 from an account with illicit funds mixed in or a series of transactions under $10,000 that total over $10,000 and are closely related.
